channel.description: Recent content in Prose on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: This course on Prose has been rewritten three times. Why? Firstly, because the original version was from years ago, when I was just starting out as a writer.

item.title: How to Write an Idea
item.description: This is the fundamental skill of every writer: turning the thoughts inside your head into prose on the page.

item.title: The Four Elements
item.description: In creative writing, we generally distinguish four different elements. These are pieces of prose with a different purpose, and therefore different advice for how to approach them.

item.title: Dialogue
item.description: This chapter on dialogue will be very brief. Why? Because I wrote a separate course on Dialogue. Click the link to visit it.

item.title: Beats
item.description: Beats are a bit special to me. Things that happen usually have a big impact. But our language is so efficient that big events can be described in very short sentences.

item.title: Description
item.description: Description is the prose type with which I struggled the most. I guess it’s because I’m a very practical and hyperactive person, which means I generally don’t have the patience to write a paragraph of description ;) My biggest task, every time I do a second draft, is to add a lot of description.

item.title: Introspection
item.description: Introspection is the type of prose that most writers tend to forget about. Especially if you approach writing from the experience of watching films or maybe theater plays.

item.title: Pyramid of Abstraction
item.description: I couldn’t decide where to place this chapter for the longest time. This is a useful concept to understand early on, but it might also be a little vague right now.

item.title: How to Revise
item.description: Welcome to the turning point in this course on Prose! The previous chapters gave you the tools for putting the thoughts in your head into words.

item.title: Vocabulary
item.description: Many people mistake being a writer for learning all sorts of fancy words. This couldn’t be further from the truth.

item.title: Punctuation
item.description: The people around me have always looked down on punctuation. Like many, they think it’s some “stupid rule” about grammar that they need to memorize for “no reason”.

item.title: Sentence Structure I
item.description: Strap in, this article will be long. In fact, I had to split the chapters about sentence structure into two parts.

item.title: Sentence Structure II
item.description: This is the second chapter about sentence structure. Probably the most important set of tips and advice about prose you will ever encounter.

item.title: Tropes
item.description: Tropes are literary techniques to enrich prose. They might not actually change the meaning or add new information, but they will make the prose sound more interesting and engaging.

item.title: Rhythm & Flow
item.description: This course is slowly moving towards bigger and more “advanced” elements of prose. Rhythm and Flow are topics that the beginning writer would probably just ignore, and that’s fine.

item.title: Paragraphs
item.description: In the chapter on Sentence Structure I told you to strap in and prepare for a long chapter, as it was the backbone of prose.

item.title: Scenes & Chapters
item.description: You are nearing the end of this course. Now that you can construct nice sentences and paragraphs, it’s time to go one step further.

item.title: Drafts, Revisions & Feedback
item.description: This chapter is about how to deal with feedback and other tips for how to structure those revisions to your prose (or story in general).

item.title: Tips & Tricks
item.description: Welcome to the final chapter in this course! Here I will give tips and tricks that didn’t easily fit elsewhere.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Congratulations! You’ve finished this course on Prose. Now go and write/read many more stories. It’s the only way to keep improving your prose.
